snippet.textDisplay:
Better game than Chrono Trigger. Fight me.

Yeah, it's not a good as a sequel but as a standalone in comparison to Trigger? This game is much deeper and more thought provoking. You have to really suspend your disbelief in Trigger as it was going for a more comedic tone, whereas Cross was a lot more serious and took itself more seriously.

snippet.textDisplay: Music and games of the 1990s were the best, even if the graphics were still elementary.  You can tell that most games during those times had a heart and soul in many aspects, game itself to the music.  Not like the games of today....pure shameless money grabs.  Specifically looking at Mobile games to be exact....but I mean there are exceptions like Breath Of the Wild, Nier Automata, and a rather good amount of other games.  But the feeling of 90s games can never be matched by today's games.

snippet.textDisplay: I got a lot of homework done with this song during high school and college. It's awesome to study during the winter with this song on. I had to drive through 4 mountains to get to my college, so it snowed a lot during the winter. The string instruments of this song with the dead winter snow fall, allowed me to concentrate through tough exams and helped me came to many realizations about life.

snippet.textDisplay:
I come from megadrive/genesis, had a "fat" ps1, and later, I bought a ps2, ps3 and now ps4. Furthermore had other consoles like gameboy, gbcolor and advance. 
But even if I didnt play this when came out, I played a while ago, and, now, there are not games like that generation had.
Its sad, but true. Another times, another sensations. Final fantasy saga in ps1, chrono trigger and chrono cross, resident evil... those talented developers had gone/lost.

Square Enix pisses me off
They've lost their vision, and their drive to deliver good, fun games. You just can't compare the Square Enix from the PS2 era and before to the one we're left with now. They used to make games because they liked to, but now it's just a bunch on money-mongering dirtbags.

snippet.textDisplay: I've been looking for a video of this music that shows different pictures of environment. I think it's a decade ago already. It's really perfect how those simple pictures capture the atmosphere of this music and I remember how everyone in the comments were contemplating over it. Did anyone here happen to see that video? I've never seen another one like it. How I wish I could watch it again... I think I've only watched it once. Life was quite busy back then. I'm pretty sure it talks about something like the environment in its title and caption. There were pictures of skies, trees and birds...

snippet.textDisplay:
Vinh Luong The I am confused as to why so many people here think that 

1. Games in the past were made with no profits in mind.

2. That games nowdays don't have the same passions as games made before.

Both of these statements are false. Everything, and I mean everything is made with Profits in mind. Even games such as Journey and Flower were made with some amount of profit margin they wanted. The difference is that there are just more games nowadays that milk their series (Ex. CoD, Assassins Creed).

However there are still dozens of dozens of games that come out full of passion, and you don't even have to look so hard for them. Overwatch, Last of Us, Zelda: Breath of the Wild, The Witcher, Even the new Call of Duty game coming out is being made after a lot of WW2 research. But none of these games are being made without profits in mind. Even a game full of passion can still be made for profit.

snippet.textDisplay:
While yes, turn-based RPG has long been an archetype, one thing that was not part of their main priority was perfect graphics, and the game focus mainly being on combat (of whatever type). This allowed for more creativity to be given to the game in other areas such as plot and  musical score. The devs could insert more of what they envision the game to be, instead of what their company envisions it to be. Their company is, of course, most concerned with making the most amount of money off their game, and adjusts the "formula" as necessary to do so. In today's market and formula, the devs spend most of their time on graphics, animation and the action within the game. Ive seen many old games, with horrible graphics and animations (even for the year it was created), but incredible plots, and music that matches the emotion of the plot or scene. You don't see this in today's archetype. Today you mostly see incredible graphics and animations, but cheesy, rehashed plot and composition. That not only applies to RPG's but virtually every game genre. 

~~Thats why a lot of these old VGMs like this are precious and revisited long after one stops playing its game, even in the PS2/Xbox era. The track itself actually meant something; had its own feel within the scene or area that it plays in. A feel that one can only understand by being there and experiencing it. 

This also holds true for those same JRPGS. Final Fantasies, as an example: Compare FF4-9 to FF13 and 14, and the shift in the archetype becomes apparent.; not that 13 and 14 aren't good games with their own positive qualities. MMO's are another example: Compare pretty much any MMO 10-12 years ago, to what it is today. 

Its simply the shift in generations, and the advancements in technology that created that shift. The majority of the new generation of gamers WANT those perfect graphics and combat, over story and music; that's what they grew up playing. Thus as a business, game companies have to change their formulas and adapt to this in order to compete, or die off. 

An example of this is Konami. A lot of geniuses from the 90s era, such as the creator of Castlevania, the creator of Megaman, the creator of Metal Gear Solid. All of them have left Konami to develop games on their own...because Konami doesn't want to publish that old archetype anymore.  (You can look this up yourself).

snippet.textDisplay: +Albatrosspro Limitations breed innovations. Look at George Lucas. When his work was limited, he made a masterpiece. The moment those limitations were broken, he began to systematically destroy his own creation. Few people can make something truly great, even with all the time and money in the world at their fingertips. Look at where Star Wars is now. Disney own the rights, and with 1 movie, they managed to do what George Lucas couldn't with 3 prequels, and 3 edited originals.

snippet.textDisplay: I think it was a function of graphical capabilities and limitations. Once "reality" came within the grasp, the goal driven by audiences, developers or both switched to a very much mistaken idea of realism.

snippet.textDisplay: Mitsuda said that he worked so much on the music day and night he fell asleep working on tracks. Thats one of the most epic and inspiring things Ive ever read about.

snippet.textDisplay:
This song makes me happy and sad simultaneously.
I never played the game, but the song itself has a nostalgic vibe to it.
It feels like you remember the past, being anxious and sad that time goes on.
But at the same time you think you can reach this blissfullness again if you give the future a chance and leave behind the past, secretly knowing probably non of it will happen, but that's ok, because you can still remember. 
Mh, yep I sure have complicated feelings, nearly went into story writing, so I cut it off. xD
Apparently the song also supports creativity.

snippet.textDisplay:
My problem with modern games is that they often seem to underestimate the power of a melodic soundtrack.
They seem to mostly rely on "ambience" and have a few notes play here and there, more or less.
I am not a fan of that kind of music, I want actual melodies.
The track in this video is a great example of a track like that, and I hope that I will eventually find some modern game with the same kind of powerful music.

Another example of a game with powerful music is the snowboarding game SSX3, especially the track "Clockworks", which reminds me a lot of Offspring.

snippet.textDisplay:
You see, it's the fact that everyone walks into something (be it games or something else) with a comparison in mind. There's always a bar to set, and apparently it's always high, *especially* when it comes to sequels of great games.

How to fix the issue? Well, everyone can enjoy a lot more things much better if *we all stopped comparing one thing to another*. That way, you can leave the nostalgia, bias, and judgement at the door and simply walk in with who you are and leave with an honest opinion. But this world isn't perfect, nonetheless.

snippet.textDisplay: What makes me mad about square-enix is that their "low budget/side projects" games (developed or publised) are pretty awesome, but they either have no marketing or are only released in Japan. On the last couple years they had Nier (that soundtrack), FF type-0 (which is amazing), Star Ocean (not bad), Dissidia, Bravery Default, Remake of Dragon Quest VII, The 3rd Birthday, And there is also some of the western games they published like Deus EX HR, Sleeping Dogs and Tomb Raider, though not RPGs

snippet.textDisplay:
A story is cut short, while another receives a second chance
And the dragon deity rules with eminence
The star stealing child, schala's clone,
Begins her journey alone,
Until she finds Serge, who fights for his own existence,
And they learn that fate is a cruel mistress...
snippet.textOriginal:
A story is cut short, while another receives a second chance
And the dragon deity rules with eminence
The star stealing child, schala's clone,
Begins her journey alone,
Until she finds Serge, who fights for his own existence,
And they learn that fate is a cruel mistress...

snippet.textDisplay:
Another world,
Where forgotten chapters leak through the dimensional veil,
Unspoken wishes across the endless oceans sail
"Where angels lose their way"
Crying upon your own grave.
Where tragic endings become joyful epilogues
And where happy poetry becomes tearful songs

Agree, at that time, chances are it being one of the finest RPGs ever, but now it would have the same chances at being flushed down the toilet first. It's like SquareEnix only cares about making fast money, not caring about gamers at all.
Remember that time when they actually put thought in plot, story and characters and spiced it up with beautiful scenaries and mind blowing music? Ah the good ol' days... hopefully some day, we'll be seeing it again. Hopefully.

snippet.textDisplay: The PS2 had more RPGs than FPSs, who was the one that left that market open for Western RPGs and FPSs took over during the PS3 era? There's HARDLY any RPGs released stateside or Europe so peoples taste in games changed, they think that they have to westernize their games for it to sell but they should be making games that rely on the JRPG strengths and use a open world structure. The lack of localization of Namco Tales Series but not Tekken boggles me to this day!

snippet.textDisplay:
After playing FFXIII and hating EVERY MINUTE OF IT will have to say that I've been disappointed with SquareEnix since Star Ocean Last Hope was released and the continuous lack of KH3 but kept releasing spinoffs, prequels and remakes

Resonance of Fate and Valkyria Chronicles are in my opinion probably the best JRPGs I've played this generation but so few have been released stateside that I ended up having to contend with western RPGs, its just not the same

I also ended up loving FPSs,

snippet.textDisplay: Amazing how much nostalgia washes over you when you hear a song from a long time ago. I was there, back in 2000, when this game was first released. The Summer of Adventure, when Square Enix was still Squaresoft, a then-glorious age of gaming. I can never have those blissful summer days back, traveling alongside heroes on an amazing journey. I learned to let go of a brief hatred I had for Lynx too. Chrono Cross, thank you for all the wonderful hours.
snippet.textOriginal: Amazing how much nostalgia washes over you when you hear a song from a long time ago. I was there, back in 2000, when this game was first released. The Summer of Adventure, when Square Enix was still Squaresoft, a then-glorious age of gaming. I can never have those blissful summer days back, traveling alongside heroes on an amazing journey. I learned to let go of a brief hatred I had for Lynx too. Chrono Cross, thank you for all the wonderful hours.

snippet.textDisplay:
The 'C' in "Chrono" is stylized the same way as in Chrono Trigger. Could it be that this game was meant to be a spiritual successor to that masterpiece?

Agh man, why did the golden age of the JRPG pass when I was in my teens; before I learned English and before I had the self-control to not obsess over games to be allowed a console. I look back on all of those games and I feel frustrated that I missed out on most of them and how the majority is inaccessible anymore.

snippet.textDisplay: Plenty of good games out there these days, but if as you get older you look at games differently. Having said that, I was really impressed with the soundtrack for FF13-2, it has some very good tracks on it that fit the story well (IMO). Having said THAT,chrono cross OST is still my favourite of all time. I have some of the titles on my IPOD right now and still listen to them regularly :)

snippet.textDisplay: @GoldenPubes I can see where you are coming from. The problem is though is that when developers make a follow up to a game as big of a hit as CT then they really can't win. If they stray too far from the original like perhaps CC than the fans moan it is too different, but if they make it too similar it gets classed as being the same old lazy shit. I thought the tie in to CT was very well handled, it didn't go overboard with it but it also didn't announce it was a direct sequel.
snippet.textOriginal: @GoldenPubes I can see where you are coming from. The problem is though is that when developers make a follow up to a game as big of a hit as CT then they really can't win. If they stray too far from the original like perhaps CC than the fans moan it is too different, but if they make it too similar it gets classed as being the same old lazy shit. I thought the tie in to CT was very well handled, it didn't go overboard with it but it also didn't announce it was a direct sequel.

snippet.textDisplay: @volkte37 Interesting take on CC. I guess some of the things you loved about it are some of the reasons I was a little disappointed- I actually disliked the loads of characters, because I felt like it really took away from character development that I really enjoyed in CT. It just really bothered me that they tried to tie CC into CT, and I think that's what really left a bad taste in my mouth. Even though I say I was disappointed, I still own the game and played it through several times. Cheers!
snippet.textOriginal: @volkte37 Interesting take on CC. I guess some of the things you loved about it are some of the reasons I was a little disappointed- I actually disliked the loads of characters, because I felt like it really took away from character development that I really enjoyed in CT. It just really bothered me that they tried to tie CC into CT, and I think that's what really left a bad taste in my mouth. Even though I say I was disappointed, I still own the game and played it through several times. Cheers!

snippet.textDisplay: @GoldenPubes I've completed both CC and CT many times and I prefer CC. I have also played plenty of RPGs over the years so must know something myself. CC has plenty of replay value, multiple endings, loads of characters to collect and items to make. I would say CT has more but CC has more than most. It is a stunning game that is foolishly hidden in the shadow of CT by journalists and 'experts'.
snippet.textOriginal: @GoldenPubes I've completed both CC and CT many times and I prefer CC. I have also played plenty of RPGs over the years so must know something myself. snippet.textDisplay: @skurtVIDEOS I never said I based my judgement on other's reviews - learn to read better. I've been playing RPG's since NES, and I've never based my judgement on another's review. I made that point because a comment was made about Chrono Trigger being a "kiddie" game and labeling it as trash, which is ridiculous. That's great you liked the game so much - wish I could have had the same experience. Either way I hope Squaresoft goes back to their roots and starts making quality games again

snippet.textDisplay: I personally played this game first before playing the original Chrono Trigger. After playing both I found that the only thing that remotely linked Trigger to Cross was the princess and Kid characters. Even then to me it was far fetched because one was about dealing with time travel and different endings (which is the more popular mechanic with the series fans imho) and the separation of the world itself into two halves. So imo each game was great in their own right.
snippet.textOriginal: I personally played this game first before playing the original Chrono Trigger. After playing both I found that the only thing that remotely linked Trigger to Cross was the princess and Kid characters. Even then to me it was far fetched because one was about dealing with time travel and different endings (which is the more popular mechanic with the series fans imho) and the separation of the world itself into two halves. So imo each game was great in their own right.

snippet.textDisplay: Chrono Cross was such a disappointment for me... Great soundtrack but really poor storyline and mediocre gameplay. snippet.textOriginal: Chrono Cross was such a disappointment for me... Great soundtrack but really poor storyline and mediocre gameplay. snippet.textDisplay: this is without question the best game I have EVER played. Everything about the game was so deep and rich with emotion, from the amazing story line, to all the wonderfully orchestrated musical scores, and especially all the heart-loved characters. This was an adventure like no other, even amongst video games. If there was ever a game that could get inside you and make you feel the moment, it was this one. Chrono Cross, you will be missed. :)

@MahamudSamatar You can buy a brand-new still wrapped copy off of Amazon for about $20.  I'm not spamming you.  I had to go through 3 copies of this game to finally finish it (Damn PS1 discs scratch easily) and when it kept freezing at a certain scene, I was glad it was so cheap at amazon. Even though I was disappointed by second disc, I'd say it's worth a place through.

This game was SO awesome at the time. Final Fantasy VII had all the JRPGs and a lot of games in general all gray and muted, just sadly fucking emo really. THEN BOOM! The music was upbeat and magical, the landscape was colorful, all the characters were vibrant and alive.

One of the best stories I've ever seen / heard / read / have been a part of.

snippet.textDisplay: @snaredrums123 I'm half in your position right now - I haven't played Chrono Cross, but I did beat Trigger literally about a week ago. I plan to try out Cross sometime soon, even if just to experience the source game of this absolutely magical soundtrack.
snippet.textOriginal: @snaredrums123 I'm half in your position right now - I haven't played Chrono Cross, but I did beat Trigger literally about a week ago. I plan to try out Cross sometime soon, even if just to experience the source game of this absolutely magical soundtrack.

snippet.textDisplay:
@snaredrums123 I was in the EXACT same position as you! Thankfully, I have beaten both games and I am proud to say I own Chrono Cross. Chrono Trigger and Cross are probably in my Top 5 of favourite games of all time!

However, I have one thing to tell you. Go into Chrono Cross without the intention of playing a direct sequel to Chrono Trigger. It is NOT a direct sequel to Trigger. It just happens to be in the same world, so there are references. Also, be really patient with Chrono Cross.
snippet.textOriginal:
@snaredrums123 I was in the EXACT same position as you! Thankfully, I have beaten both games and I am proud to say I own Chrono Cross. Chrono Trigger and Cross are probably in my Top 5 of favourite games of all time!

However, I have one thing to tell you. Go into Chrono Cross without the intention of playing a direct sequel to Chrono Trigger. It is NOT a direct sequel to Trigger. It just happens to be in the same world, so there are references. Also, be really patient with Chrono Cross.

snippet.textDisplay: I've listened to this soundtrack countless times.  And I've never played the game.  I'm actually playing through Trigger for the first time, that way I can go into Cross understanding all of the backstory.  And I am having an absolute BLAST with Trigger.  All of the characters are incredibly memorable, I love the visuals, and the battle system is absolutely boss.  I'm actually starting to see why so many people say they had high expectations for Cross, but I'll have to see for myself :)

snippet.textDisplay:
@felipe95951 It's... different. You don't even need to have played the prequel to get stuff. You just notice a few extra things and freak out for a brief moment about them. The plot is still very engaging, the artwork and backgrounds are gorgeous, and the music is simply amazing. The characters are also pretty dang memorable. Which means a lot considering the number.

It's worth a try. And considering it's an RPG, which takes hours upon hours to complete, it says a lot that I would recommend it.

I would always cry because nobody was with me to play or enjoy with it, It hurt but I kept going on.   :)

snippet.textDisplay:
@Akonkid 
If you want to know what Final Fantasy 12 was originally supposed to be like play Vagrant Story, and no Squenix won't fix it, because they didn't want it to be like Vagrant Story (and I mean tone/style/story). They wanted it to be more like Final Fantasy X. Xenogears was made by Square people who no longer work with Square. The issue isn't the games aren't there, it's that the market isn't there. Get a Wii or DS if you like the style, but don't care about the quality. JRPG's are dead.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Akonkid 
If you want to know what Final Fantasy 12 was originally supposed to be like play Vagrant Story, and no Squenix won't fix it, because they didn't want it to be like Vagrant Story (and I mean tone/style/story). They wanted it to be more like Final Fantasy X. Xenogears was made by Square people who no longer work with Square. The issue isn't the games aren't there, it's that the market isn't there. Get a Wii or DS if you like the style, but don't care about the quality. JRPG's are dead.

snippet.textDisplay: @Mugetsui go to "File"  and choose "eject cd". this will make the emulator think that you opened the system and extracted the cd. now go to "File" again and choose "insert CD Image" and search for the Disc2 file of the game. now you can continue the game. *NOTE* if you are saving the game with Freeze Files, the file will be on the Disc1 save folder because you were still playing on the disc1 emulator screen so make sure after you close the emulator to move the save file to the Disc2 save folder.
snippet.textOriginal: @Mugetsui go to "File"  and choose "eject cd". this will make the emulator think that you opened the system and extracted the cd. now go to "File" again and choose "insert CD Image" and search for the Disc2 file of the game. now you can continue the game. *NOTE* if you are saving the game with Freeze Files, the file will be on the Disc1 save folder because you were still playing on the disc1 emulator screen so make sure after you close the emulator to move the save file to the Disc2 save folder.

snippet.textDisplay: Last thing I wish to comment on is how this is one of the best rpg's that were never played. Many people who know Chrono Trigger have no clue whatsoever even about the existence of this game unless the first time they played CT (like me) was on the psx FF Chronicles disc. Needless to say, if you support this game, instead of professing how much of an RPG expert you are, spread it around where you can. This is a MUST play game and is one that will forever be remembered, and not forgotten.

Needless to say, if you support this game, instead of professing how much of an RPG expert you are, spread it around where you can. snippet.textDisplay: @MissPiddelin The entire mood of this RPG is one of nostalgia. I want to comment on the fact that this is a direct sequel to Chrono Trigger, yet again, is its own rpg, a brand new combat system (which has plenty of depth) a brand new twist to the series and aspects of Space/Time travel, with a plethora of unique and cool characters. Some are strange and there isn't a lot of background, but others you get the full blown story or description of their history.
snippet.textOriginal: @MissPiddelin The entire mood of this RPG is one of nostalgia. I want to comment on the fact that this is a direct sequel to Chrono Trigger, yet again, is its own rpg, a brand new combat system (which has plenty of depth) a brand new twist to the series and aspects of Space/Time travel, with a plethora of unique and cool characters. Some are strange and there isn't a lot of background, but others you get the full blown story or description of their history.

snippet.textDisplay: @MissPiddelin While noux22 might not be the most literate supporter of this game, I for one agree with him that it is the greatest rpg of all time. In my opinion it was a step up from Chrono Trigger in every single way, but a unique game in its own right. I have never been more moved by a soundtrack in any game, let alone the various situations and predicaments each character faces. This effect fully hits you when you see in both worlds nothing is ever perfect.
snippet.textOriginal: @MissPiddelin While noux22 might not be the most literate supporter of this game, I for one agree with him that it is the greatest rpg of all time. snippet.textDisplay:
The PSX generation of RPGs were beyond amazing. Chrono Cross, Final Fantasy VII-FFIX, Legend of the Dragoon, Parasite Eve, Dragon Quest VII, Valkyrie Profile, Vagrant Story, Xenogears... What happened to all those amazing games? New, daring, and exciting original stories? Where are the games with stories and characters that actually tug at your heartstrings and let their stories and gameplay shine?

The last great RPG for me was Lost Odyssey.
snippet.textOriginal:
The PSX generation of RPGs were beyond amazing. Chrono Cross, Final Fantasy VII-FFIX, Legend of the Dragoon, Parasite Eve, Dragon Quest VII, Valkyrie Profile, Vagrant Story, Xenogears... What happened to all those amazing games? New, daring, and exciting original stories? Where are the games with stories and characters that actually tug at your heartstrings and let their stories and gameplay shine?

The last great RPG for me was Lost Odyssey.

snippet.textDisplay: @RichterBelmontITA Well you know now that they have the graphics on point I don't think it would be to much to ask them to concentrate a little more on the story at this point. I mean look at it this way: back when the story was awesome the graphics were top notch for their time. I just think the folks have become a bit lazy or its just so much work to do all the graphics. With that in mind, a good RPG may take more than a couple years to perfect. Can you wait? I think I could.

snippet.textDisplay: One of the most beautiful pieces of music ever, in any format.  Even though the melody is touching, the underlying sadness of the song sometimes makes it hard to listen to.  It evokes a feeling of a far-off paradise, one that you know you can never return to but that you still can't let go of, because it represents the most cherished part of you.  The song is more powerful the older the game gets, because you feel the joy of your childhood slipping further and further away...
snippet.textOriginal: One of the most beautiful pieces of music ever, in any format.  Even though the melody is touching, the underlying sadness of the song sometimes makes it hard to listen to.  It evokes a feeling of a far-off paradise, one that you know you can never return to but that you still can't let go of, because it represents the most cherished part of you.  The song is more powerful the older the game gets, because you feel the joy of your childhood slipping further and further away...

snippet.textDisplay: One of my most favorite RPG tracks of all time.  Love how the assumingly "cheerful" and "free" song envelops such a sad, crying violin longing for comfort and a way out. snippet.textDisplay:
@TheSlickAndroid Because Square-Penix pissed the creators of Crono Trigger/Crono Cross/Xenogears off with their shift towards the corporate bullshit, and they just didn't want to stand for it. Thus, the Crono Series got the axe and Square-Penix went on to make FFX-2 and all the other spin-offs of fucking Final Fantasy 7.
Hell, we can't even enjoy a fan-made continuation of the Chrono Trigger storyline because Square's strangle hold on everything that they have published.

Some ask why I have a chip on my shoulder about Sony and Square. I tell them, "Go play Chrono Trigger, then go play Chrono Cross. Then YOU tell me."

Eh?

This track has been one of my personal faves for many years, ever since I first played that game (the opening theme music almost made me faint back then), but Pachelbel's Canon?  Really?

snippet.textDisplay: I live in New Jersey, by the shore, and every time i go to the beach (which is quite often) i think of either this song or the Dragoon Roost Island theme from LoZ: Wind Waker. Chrono Cross has the best, most diverse soundtrack of all time. Mistuda is a genius when it comes to blending all cultural styles together to create something unique, something that leaves the world breathless. Chrono Cross is damn close to a perfect game as i have ever seen. Heres to hoping for a sequel.

snippet.textDisplay: I gotta admit, SquareSoft and the very early years of SquareEnix were amazing.  It's nice to know that a "video game" company actually puts their hardest effort into creating music that are classified as masterpieces in the gaming industry. Much mutuality, SupraDarky! I too am an avid VGM fan! Here is a sampling of my favorites:

* Marvel Vs Capcom - Roll theme

* Vampire Savior - Vanity Paradise stage

* Tekken Tag Tournament - Mid Boss  stage, Yoshimitsu stage

* Fighting Street (Turbo Grafix 16) - Any stage (quite possibly the best VGM you'll ever hear!)

* Street Fighter 2 Sing - Chun Li theme

* Street Fighter Tribute Album - Guile theme

* Puzzle Fighter 2 - Sakura theme (I Want You To Know)
snippet.textOriginal:
Much mutuality, SupraDarky! I too am an avid VGM fan! Here is a sampling of my favorites:

* Marvel Vs Capcom - Roll theme

* Vampire Savior - Vanity Paradise stage

* Tekken Tag Tournament - Mid Boss  stage, Yoshimitsu stage

* Fighting Street (Turbo Grafix 16) - Any stage (quite possibly the best VGM you'll ever hear!)

* Street Fighter 2 Sing - Chun Li theme

* Street Fighter Tribute Album - Guile theme

* Puzzle Fighter 2 - Sakura theme (I Want You To Know)

Haha, given that the many of the events you see unfold in C.C. are a direct result of Lavos's defeat (and subsequently hiding itself in time) and Lucca's failsafe in the FATE system I don't see how C.C. could be considered anything but a sequel to C.T.; I mean come on, two of the important characters from the game were the root of all of this mess.
Then there's the Dead Sea itself... anyway, short of saying I AM THE SEQUEL TO C.T. I don't see how they could have made it more obvious.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm starting to think you're -trying- to argue lol.  Like I said, it's a 'bridge' (i.e. it's not sequential; it was more of a game made for fans, and CC was made on a whim afterward) between the two games.  that being said, the information it gives is ultimately unnecessary, but it -does- give a lot more information about Kid and Guile's past.

I don't see why you're so tenacious to think that cc isn't a sequel when it clearly (factually, even) is.  Oh well, I'm done trying to persuade you. :)
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm starting to think you're -trying- to argue lol. snippet.textDisplay:
I've said this about 3 times on other videos. The developers themselves said that CC is the true sequel to CT, and it doesn't get any clearer than that. They said CC does not occur in a parallel universe and continues on the storyline of CT. Check the CC Ultimania for this info.

I only mentioned that the main CT characters are in CC because my previous comment was a reply to someone else who didn't know it.

If not for the developer's words I wouldn't have said CC was a direct sequel either.
snippet.textOriginal:
I've said this about 3 times on other videos. The developers themselves said that CC is the true sequel to CT, and it doesn't get any clearer than that. They said CC does not occur in a parallel universe and continues on the storyline of CT. Check the CC Ultimania for this info.

Crono, Lucca and Marle's fate were all very explicitly shown in Chrono Cross, as part of its central storyline. Also take note that CC is a direct sequel to Chrono Trigger.

And agreed, I'd love to see another Chrono game either way.

snippet.textDisplay: Only problem is that oceanic island climates, even in fairly high latitudes, don't usually see that much temperature variation between summer and winter that would make for really colorful springs and autumns.  (Think of Ireland as an example; the summers are cool and grassy-green while the winters get rather little snow.  I don't think the fall colors are very vibrant there due to all the mildness and gradualness of the seasons.  Spring probably looks much the same way.

snippet.textDisplay: Actually, this isn't an original composition for Chrono Cross.  It's from an earlier game that was released for an obscure satellite only game for the Snes called 'Radical Dreamers'.  Yasunori Mitsuda composed the music for that game also.  Download the SPC soundtrack at Zohpar's Domain and listen to it.  It's a beautiful soundtrack!  I love it! :)
snippet.textOriginal: Actually, this isn't an original composition for Chrono Cross.  It's from an earlier game that was released for an obscure satellite only game for the Snes called 'Radical Dreamers'.  Yasunori Mitsuda composed the music for that game also.  Download the SPC soundtrack at Zohpar's Domain and listen to it.  It's a beautiful soundtrack!  I love it! :)
